page.title: 07EMPLOYMENT ERDINGTON
page.content: Most parents were working. The jobs varied enormously. Several mothers are dinner-ladies or work as barmaids. Some fathers and brothers worked in the building trade either self-employed or for a firm. They did jobs like plastering, brick-laying, electricians. One brother is a equestrian artist. He goes to horse and greyhound races and has exhibitions of his work. Older brothers and sisters work in banks and building societies. Some are on Youth Training Schemes or secretarial course. One father lays sewer pipes and has been a bus driver for 25 years, another works in Germany and one lectures at a University in Iraq. He has been unable to join his family. Some mothers are employed as domestic staff in hospitals, or school cleaners. Many pupils work in shops.
